column3: it may be helpful to keep sheets and a comforter nearby. not only can these help keep you and the couch clean

column6: and may help you break the habit of drifting off on the couch."

column1: "question": "what is the 24-hour sleep-wake cycle also known as?"
"passage": "sleep comes sporadically for babies in this age range. most sleep throughout the day and night
column2: and are typically awake for no longer than three hours at a time. the 24 - hour sleep - wake cycle known as circadian rhythm guides healthy sleep for children and adults. this cycle involves production of hormones that make us alert during the day and tired at night. babies are not born with a fully functioning circadian rhythm. instead
column3: they slowly develop a rhythm during the first three months of life. at 8 to 9 weeks
column4: their bodies begin to produce hormones that align with circadian cycles."

column1: "question": "what effect does yoga have on sleep?"
"yoga can improve sleep for a variety of different populations"
"text": "yoga can improve sleep for a variety of different populations"
"passage": "many studies demonstrate that yoga can improve sleep for a variety of different populations. these studies typically focus on one's quality of sleep rather than the quantity

column3: it usually includes feeling energized for the day and a lack of disturbances. yoga has been shown to help benefit all age ranges and improve sleep. from children to the elderly
column4: yoga provides numerous health and sleep benefits. for instance
column5: sleep disorders are common among children with autism spectrum disorder."

column1: "question": "how different is treatment of narcolepsy in children from adults?"
"additional precautions may be taken when choosing medications and their dosages"
"passage": "not all medications work for all patients
column2: and some patients may experience more bothersome side effects or interactions with other drugs. working closely with the doctor can help identify the medication and dosage with the best balance of benefits and downsides. treatment for children with narcolepsy is similar to treatment in adults
column3: but additional precautions may be taken when choosing medications and their dosages. a cardiovascular evaluation is recommended by the american academy of pediatrics before children start taking stimulant medications. there is limited data about the safety of most drugs used to treat narcolepsy in women who are pregnant
column4: trying to get pregnant
column5: or breastfeeding. a survey found that the majority of experts recommend stopping narcolepsy medications when trying to conceive as well as when pregnant and breastfeeding. discontinuing medication may require changes to behavioral approaches and other accommodations to safely cope with symptoms without medication."

column3: but additional precautions may be taken when choosing medications and their dosages. a cardiovascular evaluation is recommended by the american academy of pediatrics before children start taking stimulant medications. there is limited data about the safety of most drugs used to treat narcolepsy in women who are pregnant
column4: trying to get pregnant

column1: "question": "when is it worth considering a split mattress?"
"if your partner's body type and/or position preferences are entirely different from yours"
"text": "if your partner's body type and / or position preferences are entirely different from yours"

column2: sleepers on firmer mattresses may need a thicker pillow to adequately cushion and support the neck. while firmness can greatly impact how your bed feels and performs
column3: there are also many other factors to consider when selecting a mattress. when selecting a mattress to share
column4: it is important to consider the needs and preferences of both partners. many couples compromise by choosing a sleep surface between their preferred firmness levels. however
column5: if your partner's body type and / or position preferences are entirely different from yours
column6: it may be worth considering a split mattress. overheating is a common problem that can disrupt quality rest."

column1: "question": "what stage of sleep is the one in which we do the most dreaming?"

column2: our brain cycles through different stages of sleep several times a night
column3: from light sleep to deep sleep to rapid eye movement ( rem ) sleep and back again. with each cycle
column4: we spend progressively more time in the deeper rem stages of sleep
column5: and less time in light sleep. when you cut your sleep time short
column6: you cut your rem sleep short. rem sleep is the stage of sleep in which we do the most dreaming
column7: and our brains process new information and commit it to memory. rem sleep is critical for our cognitive performance."

"passage": "the study involves using a cpap device during a polysomnography test

column1: "question": "why can coil support cores regulate temperature well?"

"text": "as air can freely travel through the coils"
"passage": "each material confers certain benefits and drawbacks
column2: and understanding how different support core materials alter a bed's performance can help you predict how a mattress will feel. historically
column3: most mattresses were constructed using a coil support core. the coils are designed to flex when pressure is added and return almost immediately to their original shape when pressure is lifted. as a result

column5: as air can freely travel through the coils."

column1: "passage": "nocturnal sleep - related eating disorder ( ns - red ) is a parasomnia where individuals eat food during the night while they are asleep
column2: and have no recollection of it upon waking up. women are significantly more likely to have ns - red. ns - red can occur during sleepwalking and may coexist with other sleep disorders that trigger sleep eating. ns - red can be treated with medication
column3: therapy
column4: stress management techniques
column5: and lifestyle changes
column6: such as limiting caffeine and alcohol. restless legs syndrome ( rls ) causes unpleasant crawling and tingling sensations in the legs
column7: which occur when lying down and are accompanied by an uncontrollable urge to move the legs."

column1: "the period between spring and fall when many people change their clocks forward one hour."
"text": "the period between spring and fall when many people change their clocks forward one hour"

column2: people adjust their clocks forward by one hour in the spring to mark the beginning of daylight saving time. this special period of timekeeping then ends in the fall. learn more about this practice
column3: including where it originated
column4: why countries continue to engage in it
column5: and what alternatives are being proposed. daylight saving time ( dst ) is the period between spring and fall when many people change their clocks forward one hour. currently
column6: in the united states
column7: people spring forward by setting clocks ahead an hour the second sunday in march and fall back by setting clocks back an hour the first sunday in november."

column1: "question": "what should you do if you regularly have trouble falling asleep?"
"passage": "if you regularly have trouble falling asleep
column2: talk to your doctor. they can advise you on better sleep hygiene or refer you to a specialist to check for a sleep disorder. dreams primarily occur during rem sleep. in addition to dreaming
column3: your brain also uses this stage of sleep to make sense of your emotions
column4: process learnings from the day
column5: and decide what to commit to memory. researchers have identified a particular set of neurons that play a key role in helping your brain forget new information it has deemed unimportant
column6: which may include dreams. these neurons activate during rem sleep."

column1: "needing to wake up at night in order to urinate."
"text": "needing to wake up at night in order to urinate"
"passage": "understanding the basics about frequent nighttime urination
column2: including its causes
column3: consequences
column4: and treatments
column5: can be a first step for people of any age to sleep better and with less bothersome nocturia. nocturia describes needing to wake up at night in order to urinate. it is a symptom of other conditions
column6: not a disease itself. according to technical definitions
column7: a person has nocturia if they get out of bed to urinate one or more times per night. by this standard
column8: nocturia is widespread ; however
column9: many people may not find one awakening to be problematic. nocturia tends to be more bothersome when a person awakens two or more times and / or if they have difficulty getting back to sleep."

column1: "a neurodevelopmental disorder that involves reduced attention span and increased impulsiveness"
"text": "a neurodevelopmental disorder that involves reduced attention span and increased impulsiveness."

"passage": "attention - deficit / hyperactivity disorder ( adhd ) is a neurodevelopmental disorder that involves reduced attention span and increased impulsiveness. adhd is usually diagnosed in children
column2: but it may last into adulthood and is sometimes only formally diagnosed when someone is already an adult. sleeping problems are common in people with adhd. they may have difficulty falling asleep
column3: frequent awakenings
column4: and excessive daytime sleepiness. rates of other sleeping problems
column5: such as obstructive sleep apnea and restless leg syndrome ( rls ) also appear to be higher in people with adhd. sleep difficulties associated with adhd have been studied primarily in children but have been found to affect adults as well."

column1: "question": "what is a cause of short term insomnia?"

column2: seeing the inability to sleep as a natural reaction to a potential threat. the good news is that while more stress can lead to worse sleep

column4: rather than higher levels of stress per se
column5: was the primary factor affecting sleep quality. finding ways to cope with stress may reduce the negative effects of stress on sleep
column6: even for those with high - stress lifestyles. studies have also found that sleep can improve quickly after a temporary stressor ends."

column1: "question": "why is it important to talk with a doctor before starting to take any sleep aid?"

column1: "question": "how does the body normally react to the darkness at night?"

column2: a hormone that signals that it's time to sleep"
a hormone that signals that it's time to sleep."
the body normally reacts to the darkness by releasing melatonin
column3: a hormone that signals that it's time to sleep. however
column4: our brains are very sensitive to light
column5: and the blue light emitted from cell phones and other electronic devices delays melatonin production. lack of melatonin can make it difficult to fall asleep
column6: which can lead to insomnia and fatigue over time. studies also suggest that blue light can decrease the amount of time the body spends in slow - wave sleep and rapid eye movement ( rem ) sleep. these two sleep stages are important for consolidating memories and regulating mood."

column1: "question": "what does a predictable routine do for your child?"
"gives your child a sense of security and teaches them how to fall asleep on their own"
"text": "gives your child a sense of security and teaches them how to fall asleep on their own"

"passage": "they help prepare your child for sleep by having them relax and wind down. a predictable routine also gives your child a sense of security and teaches them how to fall asleep on their own. research shows that children who follow bedtime routines are more likely to go to sleep earlier
column2: take less time falling asleep
column3: sleep longer
column4: and wake up less during the night. these benefits to sleep quality are still seen years later in children who followed bedtime routines when they were younger. in addition to improving sleep
column5: bedtime routines teach your child self - care and lay the ground for working memory
column6: attention
column7: and other cognitive skills."

column1: "question": "what causes changes in heart rate during sleep?"
"passage": "other recent studies have continued to find white noise positively affecting sleep. for example
column2: people living in a high - noise area of new york city fell asleep faster and spent more of their time in bed asleep while listening to white noise. in another study
column3: listening to white noise through headphones improved sleep quality for critically ill patients in a loud hospital unit in india. more research is needed to confirm whether an inherent characteristic of white noise improves sleep - perhaps by synchronizing brain waves - or if the sound primarily helps by masking background noise. disruptive noise during sleep can cause changes in heart rate that suggest the sleeper is experiencing semi - awakenings."

column5: approximately 76 countries

column1: "question": "what does it mean to pull an all-nighter?"
"intentionally staying awake throughout the night with little to no sleep"
"text": "intentionally staying awake throughout the night with little to no sleep."

"passage": "pulling an all - nighter means intentionally staying awake throughout the night with little to no sleep. there are many reasons why people pull all - nighters. some people sacrifice sleep in order to meet work deadlines or study for exams. others have job schedules that require them to work through the night and sleep during the day. with proper sleep recovery in the days that follow
column2: an occasional all - nighter probably will not cause lasting health effects. however
column3: research shows sleep deprivation night after night can lead to poor cognitive performance
column4: fatigue
column5: and higher levels of stress and anxiety."

column1: "passage": "certain materials tend to create a more stable surface for heavier sleepers. for example

column6: but you should always make sure the base is compatible with your mattress model."

column1: "question": "what is prescribed as first line treatment for obesity?"

column5: many osa patients want to know which one is best for sleep apnea. doctors usually prescribe dietary and exercise interventions as a first - line treatment for obesity. obese patients who are unlikely or unable to achieve adequate weight loss through behavior modifications may consider pharmacological or surgical interventions."

column2: by constructing the mattress with breathable materials and leaving room for airflow

column1: "question": "how many adults wake up during the night three or more nights per week?"
"passage": "if you're regularly waking up during the night
column2: you're not alone. nearly 48 % of adults wake up during the night three or more nights per week. many factors might explain your interrupted sleep
column3: from a snoring sleep partner to your own racing thoughts. whatever the cause
column4: a restless night's sleep is frustrating. in fact
column5: it's one of the main reasons people rate their sleep quality as poor. people who wake up during the night consistently view their sleep quality as poor
column6: while those who enjoy uninterrupted sleep tend to think they sleep well. waking up during the night isn't only bad for your sleep."

column3: the amount of daily sleep they need decreases. these sleep needs are initially distributed between naps and nighttime sleep
column4: but at what age should kids stop napping? the exact age varies among children
column5: depending on factors such as attending preschool
column6: maturity
column7: and nighttime sleep habits."

"passage": "sleep disorders cause many troubling symptoms that can affect one's mood
column2: energy level
column3: and overall health. unfortunately

column5: if any

column1: "partial or complete obstructions of the airway"
"text": "multiple partial or complete obstructions of the airway"
"passage": "obstructive sleep apnea ( osa ) is a common sleep disorder
column2: believed to affect at least 2 % to 4 % of people. during sleep
column3: people with osa experience multiple partial or complete obstructions of the airway
column4: termed hypopneas and apneas. additional symptoms may include loud snoring
column5: gasping or choking
column6: and daytime sleepiness. if you have recently received a diagnosis of sleep apnea or taken a sleep study
column7: you may have noticed an ahi reading on your results. ahi is short for apnea - hypopnea index. this is a scale doctors use when diagnosing obstructive sleep apnea ( osa ). the apnea - hypopnea index ( ahi ) is a diagnostic tool for determining the presence and severity of obstructive sleep apnea ( osa )."

column1: "question": "when have researchers noticed that false awakenings often occur?"

column2: such as a sleep disruption"

column8: anxiety
column9: or a noisy environment
column10: which may contribute to rem sleep hyperarousal."

column1: "question": "how do you predict durability for innerspring and hybrid mattresses?"
"text": "look for a lower coil gauge ( which means thicker coils )"

column2: lasting upwards of 8 years. depending on the material
column3: there are a few good ways to predict durability. for innerspring and hybrid mattresses
column4: look for a lower coil gauge ( which means thicker coils ). for mattresses with foam
column5: look for higher foam densities ( 1. 7 + pcf for polyfoam
column6: 5 + pcf for memory foam ). finally
column7: make sure you're getting natural latex rather than synthetic latex. maintenance & care - like any other product
column8: a mattress will last longer if you take good care of it. this means rotating your mattress every 3 months or so ( unless the manufacturer recommends otherwise ) and utilizing a mattress protector."
